description: First attested in 1687. snug +‎ -le (frequentative suffix); spelt with doubled ‘g’ to clarify pronunciation.

examples: Let's have a snuggle on the sofa.

entries.meaning: The final remnant left in a liquor bottle.

verbs.description: snuggle (third-person singular simple present snuggles, present participle snuggling, simple past and past participle snuggled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To lie close to another person or thing, hugging or being cosy.
examples: Sometimes my girlfriend and I snuggle.
The surrounding buildings snuggled each other.
The last drop of jager snuggled the corner of the pint.

entries.meaning: To move or arrange oneself in a comfortable and cosy position.
examples: Tired but satisfied, the children snuggled into their sleeping bags.
The pet dog snuggles into its new bed.
